The Short Way Round
This season we follow Karl trough the seven wonders of the world! Watch him point out how the great wall of china isn\'t so great, amongst other things.
This season we follow Karl as Ricky and Stephen send him fullfill other peoples bucket list. Karl does not really like to do things.

This season we follow Karl trough the footsteps of Marco Polo, and this time he is invited by the friendly little peron, Warrick! Watch as Karl looks forward to seeing Warrick live in the same bad conditions he did last time. (Except this time Ricky and Stephen gives Warrick luxury living.)
I thought I\'d seen the Great Wall of China. Which, being honest with you, it\'s not the Great Wall; it\'s an alright wall. It\'s the Alright Wall of China.

You know, you can see it for miles - goes on for miles, over the hills and everything. But, so does the M6. Do you know what I mean? You can see that for miles. And you go great. And that does a job. You can drive on that.
Camels have been around for years. The ships of the desert. That\'s what they\'re known as. We\'ve ended up with Titanic.
It\'s like a game of Jenga that\'s got out of hand.

I say happiness is like having a cake. If you have a cake every day, you get sick of that cake. If you\'re happy all the time, you get sick of being happy. That\'s a good saying actually. Happiness is like a cake - have too much of it, you get sick of it.

[Which super power would you have, Karl?]I\'d be bullshit man. There\'s so many meetings going on where, you know people are bullshitting. I\'d just like to walk in. I wouldn\'t need a special costume, just dressed like this and I would fly in and I\'d go, "Bullshit. He\'s talking bullshit." And they\'d go, "Oh. He\'s Bullshit Man." And I\'d go, "Yea. It is Bullshit Man. You\'re talking bullshit." And eventually, people would stop talking bullshit. Anything that\'s going on in the world: A bloke selling a car that\'s knackered, and he\'s going to say it\'s a great one, and it\'s [whoosh] Bullshit!
Sharks are always dangerous. Jaws, Shark Attack One, Two, and Three. Three films there. There was a chance for him to get friendly. Didn\'t. An angry shark for three films.
You should see the crowds here when Warwick was walking down the street. It\’s the same thing. People just like seeing little oddities in life.
I will kick a panda in the bollocks if I have to.
It looks like we\'ve been doing the London marathon and got lost.

India
China
A Commentary
The official name of China is the "People\'s Republic of China".
China is the world\'s most populous country.
China is a single party state governed by the Communist Party.
China is the world 2nd largest country after Russia.
Construction on the Great Wall started during the 7th century BCE
The Great wall is in fact not visible from the moon.
Beijing the capital of China has a population of over 20 million.
Beijing hosted the 2008 Summer Olympics.
The Forbidden City was the seat of the Chinese emperors for almost 500 years.
There is not language called Chinese. The two most widely spoken languages are called Mandarin and Cantonese.
The capital of Inidia is New Delhi.
Two of the world\'s four largest religions originated in India.
One of the most popular sports in India is cricket.
The Taj Mahal is in fact a mausoleum.
The Kumbh Mela festival is the largest peaceful gathering in the world. In 2013 over 100 million people participated.
India was in colonized by the East India Company in the late 18th and early 19th century.
The Indian independence movement was lead by Mahatma Gandhi by employing non-violent civil disobedience.
When India achieved their independence is was split into two countries, India and Pakistan.
India is in constant disputes with Pakistan over the control of the Kashmir region.
India has a thriving film industry, mostly known for their Bollywood films.
Jordan was created after the first world war and gained independence after the second world war.
Jordan is a constitutional monarchy, King Abdullah II is the head of state.
Petra is an ancient historical city carved into rock in southern Jordan. It is one of the new seven wonders of the world.
Petra is also known as the Rose City because of the color of the rock it is carved from.
The Dead Sea lies between Jordan and Israel. It is the lowest point of dry land on earth at 423m below sea level.
In ancient times Jordan was part of the Persian, and later Mecedonian empire.
Mexico is the cradle of 2 of the greatest pre-European american civilizations; the Maya, and the Aztec.
The conquest of the Aztecs by the Spanish started in 1519 when Hernán Cortés arrived in Veracruz with 500 conquistadores.
One of the main reasons the Spanish was so effective in conquering the Aztecs was the introduction of smallpox to the American continent.
Mexico gained independence in 1821.
Texas declared independence from Mexico in 1824.
Slavery was abolished in Mexico in 1829.
After the Mexican-American war Mexico was forced to give up over half of its land, including the rest of Texas, California and New Mexico.
Chocolate is originally from Mexico.
The egyptian civilization started to form when the Sahara began to dry out forcing people to migrate to the Nile.
Egypt was unified in 3150 BCE by King Menes.
The Giza Pyramids were created during the Old Kingdom era between 2700-2200 BCE.
The pyramids were most likely build by paid workers. Not slaves.
The first time egypt was conquered was around 1650 BCE after 1500 years of native Egyptian rule.
Egypt created the first religion with only one god.
The last native pharaoh King Nectanebo was killed in 343 BCE.
The time between the building of the great pyramids and Cleopatra is longer than the time between Cleopatra and the present day.
Egypt went through a revolution in early 2011 as part of the Arab Spring.
Cairo, the capital of Egypt is the largest city in the Arab world and in Africa.
Brazil was claimed by Portugal in April 1500 although it took another 32 years for the colonization to start.
In 1808 Brazil was elevated from a colony to an official part of United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves.
Prince Pedro declared the country\'s independence from Portugal on 7 September 1822.
The monarchy was overthrown on 15 November 1889.
The world’s best and most delicious coffee is produced in Brazil.
Brazil has the biggest rain forest of the world, the Amazon forest.
Brazil has one of the New 7 Wonders of the World, the Christ Redeemer statue, located in Rio De Janeiro
The Carnival of Brazil is an annual festival held during the Friday to the Tuesday before Ash Wednesday.
The huge parades with the large floats that takes place during the carnival are competitions between samba schools
The most popular sport in Brazil is football. The Brazilian national football team is ranked among the best in the world.
Peru is the home of the Inca Empire. The largest pre-colombian state in America.
One of the most important remaining Inca sites is Machu Picchu. It was built as an estate for the Inca emperor Pachacuti and is one of the New 7 Wonders of the World.
The Peruvian Amazon forest is populated by several native tribes, some of which used to be cannibals.
In December 1532, a party of conquistadors led by Francisco Pizarro defeated and captured Inca emperor Atahualpa.
Peru declared independence from Spain in 1821.
The Nazca Lines were discovered in 1939.
Contrary to popular belief the Nazca Lines can be seen from surround hills. Not only the air

In 1974, Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain visited Vanuatu and observed the spectacle of land jumping. The British colonial administration wanted the queen to have an interesting tour, and convinced the Anglican villagers of the Melanesian Mission at Point Cross to do so. However, the vines were not elastic enough because it was the wrong season, the middle of the wet season. One diver had both lianas broken, broke his back from falling, and later died in a hospital. Until 2006, when a diver broke his spine after landing badly and subsequently died in hospital, this was the only fatality in memory.
The construction of the tower typically takes between two and five weeks of labour. Around twenty to thirty men help construct it.
Before land diving the men often bring closure to unsettled business and disputes in case they die.
The first modern bungee jumps were made on 1 April 1979 from the 76 m tall Clifton Suspension Bridge in Bristol, by members of the Oxford University Dangerous Sports Club.
Polynesians settled New Zealand in 1250–1300 CE and developed a distinctive Māori culture. Europeans first made contact in 1642 CE.

The Trans-Siberian Railway is a network of railways connecting Moscow with the Russian Far East and the Sea of Japan. It is the longest railway line in the world. There are connecting branch lines into Mongolia, China and North Korea.

Full-time construction of the Trans-Siberian Railway began in 1891. Similar to the first transcontinental railroad in the USA, Russian engineers started construction at both ends and worked towards the centre.
Moscow is the capital city of Russia. According to Forbes 2011, Moscow has the largest community of billionaires in the world.

During the French invasion of Russia in 1812, the Muscovites burned the city and evacuated, as Napoleon\’s forces were approaching on 14 September. Napoleon\’s Grande Armée, plagued by hunger, cold and poor supply lines, was forced to retreat and was nearly annihilated by the devastating Russian winter and sporadic attacks by Russian military forces.
Moscow is the heart of the Russian performing arts, including ballet and film. There are 93 theaters, 132 cinemas and 24 concert halls in Moscow.

The most obvious celebration of Songkran is the throwing of water upon others. Thais roam the streets with containers of water or water guns. The throwing of water originated as a way to pay respect to people, by capturing the water after it had been poured over the Buddhas for cleansing and then using this "blessed" water to give good fortune to elders and family by gently pouring it on the shoulder. Among young people the holiday evolved to include dousing strangers with water to relieve the heat, since April is the hottest month in Thailand. This has further evolved into water fights and splashing water over people riding in vehicles.

Muay Thai is a combat sport from the muay martial arts of Thailand that uses stand-up striking along with various clinching techniques. This physical and mental discipline which includes combat on foot is known as "the art of eight weapons" because it is characterized by the combined use of fists, elbows, knees, shins and feet.

The great white shark also known as the great white, white pointer, white shark, or white death, can be found in the coastal surface waters of all the major oceans. The great white shark is mainly known for its size, with the largest individuals known to have approached or exceeded 6 m in length.

More than any documented attack, Jaws directed by Steven Spielberg provided the great white shark with the image of being a "man eater" in the public mind. While great white sharks have killed humans, they typically do not target them: for example, in the Mediterranean Sea there have been 31 confirmed attacks against humans in the last two centuries.

Cage diving is most common at sites where great whites are frequent including the coast of South Africa, the Neptune Islands in South Australia, and Guadalupe Island in Baja California. Cage diving and swimming with sharks is a focus for a booming tourist industry due to its popularity. A common practice is to chum the water with pieces of fish to attract the sharks.

Whale watching is the practice of observing whales and dolphins in their natural habitat. Whales are watched most commonly for recreation but the activity can also serve scientific or educational purposes. A 2009 study, prepared for IFAW, estimated that 13 million people went whale watching globally in 2008.

Organized whale watching dates back to 1950 when the Cabrillo National Monument in San Diego was declared a public venue for observing Gray Whales and the spectacle attracted 10,000 visitors in its first year.
Alaska was purchased from Russia on March 30, 1867, for $7.2 million, $118 million adjusted for inflation at approximately $4.74/km².

Roald Amundsen\'s expedition to the south pole planned to use around ninety-seven sled dogs. On his first try, two of his dogs froze to death in the freezing temperatures. He tried a second time and was successful. Amundsen was covering 17 miles a day, with stops every 3 miles to build a cairn to mark the trail. He had 55 dogs with him, which he culled until he had 14 left when he returned from the pole. On the return trip, a man skied ahead of the dogs and hid meat in the cairns to encourage them to run.

Ice roads are frozen, human-made structures on the surface of bays, rivers, lakes, or seas in polar regions. They allow temporary transport to areas with no permanent road access. Ice roads differ from winter roads in that they are built primarily across frozen waterways. Ice roads may be winter substitutes for summer ferry service. Ferry service and an ice crossing may operate yearly at the same time for several weeks.
